bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, July 17, 1948

div1.p: Hench explains why he has not had time to write the yellow fever story. He hints about a possible breakthrough in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, July 17, 1948
div1.opener:
July 17, 1948
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for returning the material which
arrived in good shape. I felt sure that it would be of
great interest to you and General Kean and revive many in-
teresting memories. By separate post I am sending you our
latest Rheumatism Review for your passing interest. You
will of course not want to keep it but you might give it to
some young doctor friend as the reprints are rather scarce
but I wanted to have you see how I keep myself busy and
why I don't get further along with the yellow fever story.
I have felt a little bit the gentle pressure which you and
General Kean have put upon me to finish the book. My only
defense is as follows:

When I got into this thing, I first thought I was
merely going to publish for them the little story of Moran
and Kissinger. You know how involved I have become. I
would be ashamed to have some of my colleagues in the Clinic,
especially the Board of Governors, know how many hours I have
spent on this hobby and I am afraid I would have to plead
guilty to the charge that I have not always worked on it out
of hours. I have spent many Clinic hours on it. Nevertheless,
I have tried to maintain the fundamental principal that this
yellow fever story was after all a hobby (my chief one) and it
will be published. Nevertheless, my main contribution to
human society and to my profession and to my own professional
standing is first the daily job of making a living at the Clinic
and secondly a continuing need to try to become the finest
rheumatologist that I can become with the possible hope that I
can make a real scientific contribution to the miserable vic-
tims of chronic arthritis. Therefore, my second job after the
primary one of making a living is in the field of clinical
research over which I have spent long, long hours, not only
during Clinic hours but over weekends and long into the night.
I am not being immodest when I state that my own contribution
describing and trying to reproduce certain phenomena which
occur in rheumatoid arthritis have been considered by many the
most promising and outstanding lead ever discovered for rheuma-
toid arthritis. Just last week a visitor came from London to
talk to me about it and slowly but surely we are making progress.
General Albert E. Truby
- 2 -
July 17, 1948
We are about to embark on the most promising leads we have ever had. This in-
volves getting a special research chemist from Switzerland as we are working in
a field of chemistry which is practically untouched, getting a new $1,000 apparatus
and training a laboratory worker in special new methods. I simply cannot pause
in this extremely important work. It would be folly for me to suggest that I may be
successful but at least I must try and if we are successful our work will almost
compare with that of our mutual hero, Walter Reed. Therefore, I have had to keep
a proper prospective and even though I should love nothing better than to slow
up and put aside all except the yellow fever work, my conscience will not permit.
It has been even more painful to me than to you three very close and valuable
friends of mine that I have not yet been able to prepare the manuscript, but such
little matters as a four year service in the Army as well as lesser matters of
new discoveries and my inability yet to tap two or three very important sources
such as General Wood's diary and the Finlay Diary and the material that Carroll
probably has, have lead me to keep trying to get this material before actually
starting the manuscript. The last item I shall not wait for. The first item
I hope to get in the near future; the second I think would be very useful but
I will not necessarily wait.

Please, therefore, be patient and understanding. You may be surprised
that I have taken this opportunity to speak so frankly. Your own little gentle
hints have not precipitated the letter but the accumulation of perfectly proper hints
of encouragement have brought forth this confession.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
